questions.text: Identify the inhalational anaesthetic agent of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Desflurane

 

Option C: It has the lowest blood-gas solubility among the agents listed, allowing for rapid adjustment of depth of anesthesia and potentially quicker recovery, which is beneficial in morbidly obese patients due to reduced anesthesia time.

 

Explanation:

 

In the case of a morbidly obese patient as shown in the image, the selection of an inhalational anesthetic agent should consider the solubility of the agent and its effects on recovery time post-surgery.

 

Option A: Sevoflurane – It's commonly used due to its minimal respiratory and cardiovascular effects. However, it has a higher blood-gas solubility than desflurane, potentially leading to a longer recovery time.

 

Option B: Isoflurane – Offers stable hemodynamics and is less expensive but has a higher blood-gas solubility, which may not be ideal for rapid emergence.

 

Option D: Methoxyflurane – It's no longer used as a general anesthetic due to nephrotoxicity and high blood-gas solubility, leading to prolonged emergence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a morbidly obese patient, desflurane (Option C) is the preferred inhalational anesthetic agent due to its low blood-gas solubility, which facilitates precise control of anesthetic depth and allows for rapid emergence from anesthesia.

 

 

Ref:- Miller’s anesthesia 9th edition pg 610

questions.text: During an Anesthetic procedure, a 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension accidentally receives an intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone. Immediately after the injection, he reports severe pain at the injection site and the affected limb becomes pale. Which of the following is the most likely complication this patient is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ischemia

 

Explanation:-

 

Option A. Inadvertent intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone can lead to severe complications, the most likely of which in this patient is ischemia. This occurs because the injection of the drug directly into an artery can cause thrombosis, vasospasm, and a lack of blood flow to the affected limb, resulting in ischemia. The initial symptom is typically burning pain, and the affected limb may become pale due to vasospasm. This complication is commonly seen when thiopentone is injected in antecubital vein because in 10% of the case brachial artery divides above elbow giving a very superficial abnormal ulnar artery which lies deep to antecubital vein. Therefore, thiopentone injection should be avoided at antecubital fossa and it should be given in the veins over the outer aspect of forearm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inadvertent intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone can lead to complications such as ischemia, which can result in severe pain and pallor in the affected limb due to thrombosis and vasospasm. It is essential to avoid injecting Thiopentone into arteries to prevent this complication.

 

The management of intra-arterial injection of thiopentone includes –

 

  • Leaving Needle in situ in the Artery
  • Brachial Plexus Block (Stellate Ganglion Block)
  • Heparin Injection → To prevent Thrombosis.
  • Dilution of Thiopental by injection of Saline into the Artery
  • Papaverine or Prostacyclin injection – to relieve Spasm.
  • Urokinase, Streptokinase, Vasodilators, Steroid and Lignocaine can also be used in uncompensated Myocardial Disease.

 

 

REF: Miller's Anesthesia 9th edition • Page no. 832

choices.text: It causes rise in Intracranial Pressure.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with ischemic heart disease is sedated, ventilated in the ICU. You would not prefer Etomidate for continuous sedation in this patient because?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It results in Adrenal Suppression.

 

Option A. This statement is correct. Etomidate can lead to adrenal suppression by inhibiting 11 beta-hydroxylase, an enzyme involved in corticosteroid synthesis in the adrenal cortex. This inhibition can result in decreased synthesis of adrenal corticosteroids, which is a significant concern, especially in critically ill patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. It may cause Vasospasm: This statement is not a typical side effect of Etomidate. Etomidate is not known for causing vasospasm as one of its primary effects. Instead, it is more commonly associated with adrenal suppression and potential cardiovascular effects.

 

Option C. It results in Cardiac Arrhythmias: Etomidate is generally considered to have a relatively stable cardiovascular profile and is less likely to cause cardiac arrhythmias compared to some other anesthetic agents. It is often used in patients with compromised cardiovascular function.

 

Option D. It causes a rise in Intracranial Pressure: Etomidate is actually known for causing a decrease in intracranial pressure, which can be advantageous in some situations, such as when managing patients with traumatic brain injury or increased intracranial pressure. It has a cerebral protective effect by reducing cerebral metabolic rate and intracranial pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Etomidate is avoided for continuous sedation in critically ill patients due to its potential to cause adrenal suppression, which can increase the risk of mortality, especially in patients with ischemic heart disease or other critical conditions.

 

 

REF: Morgan and Mikhail’s Anesthesiology 7th edition page 334-336

questions.text: In which of the below conditions will Ketamine be most preferred in?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyper-Reactive Airways

 

Option C. This is the correct answer. Ketamine is a potent bronchodilator and is often preferred in patients with hyper-reactive airways, such as those with asthma, because it can relieve bronchospasm and maintain airway function.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ischemic Heart Disease: Ketamine is generally avoided in patients with ischemic heart disease because it can increase cardiac oxygen demand and blood pressure, which can be detrimental in such patients.

 

Option B. Intracranial Hemorrhage: Ketamine is contraindicated in patients with intracranial hemorrhage as it can increase intracranial pressure, potentially worsening the condition.

 

Option D. Glaucoma: Ketamine is contraindicated in patients with glaucoma as it can significantly increase intraocular pressure, which can be harmful to the eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ketamine is most preferred in patients with hyper-reactive airways (hyperresponsive or reactive airways, such as asthma) because it acts as a potent bronchodilator and can relieve bronchospasm.

 

 

REF: Morgan and Mikhail’s Anaesthesiology 7th edition page 332

choices.text: Induction Dose is 3-5 mg/kg of 2.5% Thiopentone.
It Reduces ICP and is Cerebroprotective
It is Ultra-Short Acting due to Rapid Metabolism & Excretion.
Intra-Arterial Injection cause Pain & Vasospasm

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding Thiopentone?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is Ultra-Short Acting due to Rapid Metabolism & Excretion.

 

Option C. This statement is not true. Thiopentone is ultra-short acting primarily due to rapid redistribution of the drug from the brain to other tissues in the body, rather than rapid metabolism and excretion. This redistribution leads to the rapid termination of its anesthetic effects.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option A. Induction Dose is 3-5 mg/kg of 2.5% Thiopentone: This statement is true. The typical induction dose of Thiopentone is 3-5 mg/kg of a 2.5% solution. The dose may vary depending on the patient's age, weight, and specific clinical circumstances.

 

Option B. It Reduces ICP and is Cerebroprotective: This statement is true. Thiopentone is considered cerebroprotective because it Reduces Intra-Cranial Pressure (ICP) by depressing cerebral metabolism. It can be used in patients with raised ICP and seizures to help manage intracranial hypertension.

 

Option D. Intra Intra-Arterial Injection cause Pain & Vasospasm: This statement is true. Intra-arterial injection of Thiopentone is associated with pain at the injection site and vasospasm, which can lead to adverse effects, including potential ischemia in the affected limb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiopentone is an ultra-short-acting intravenous induction agent primarily due to rapid redistribution, not rapid metabolism and excretion.

 

 

REF: Morgan and Mikhail’s Anesthesiology 7th edition page 318-324

questions.text: Which of these intravenous induction agents is preferred in cardiac surgeries?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Etomidate

 

Explanation:

 

In cardiac surgeries, Etomidate is often the preferred intravenous induction agent. This is because Etomidate is the most Cardio-Stable (Hemodynamically Stable) among the intravenous induction agents. It causes the least hemodynamic disturbance, making it suitable for patients with cardiac disease, such as heart failure, valve dysfunction, or those undergoing aneurysm, bypass, or valve surgery.

 

Other intravenous induction agents like Propofol, Thiopental, and Barbiturates can cause dose-dependent vasodilation and hypotension, which may not be well-tolerated in patients with compromised cardiac function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Etomidate is the preferred intravenous induction agent in cardiac surgeries due to its minimal impact on hemodynamic, making it a safe choice for patients with cardiac conditions undergoing surgical procedures.

 

 

REF: Morgan and Mikhail’s Anaesthesiology 7th edition page 335

choices.text: It is Milky White in Colour.
It is an Emulsion with Egg Lecithin present in it.
It is considered the Best Agent for Day Care Surgery.
It is associated with High Incidence of Nausea and Vomiting.

questions.text: All are true about the drug shown in the image except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It is associated with High Incidence of Nausea and Vomiting.

 

Option D. It is associated with a high incidence of nausea and vomiting: This statement is not true. Propofol is known for its antiemetic properties and is often used to prevent nausea and vomiting during and after surgery.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option.

 

Option A. It is Milky White in Colour: This statement is true. Propofol is a milky white intravenous emulsion.

 

Option B. It is an Emulsion with Egg Lecithin present in it: This statement is true. Propofol is formulated as an emulsion that contains soybean oil, egg lecithin, and glycerol.

 

Option C. It is considered the Best Agent for Day Care Surgery: This statement is true. Propofol is often considered an excellent choice for day care or ambulatory surgeries due to its rapid onset and short duration of action, allowing for a quick recovery and discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propofol is commonly used in anesthesia due to its rapid onset of action, short duration, and antiemetic properties. Understanding its characteristics and benefits is important for anesthesia providers and healthcare practitioners.

 

 

REF: Morgan and Mikhail’s Anaesthesiology 7th edition page 336-340

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is scheduled for a minor ambulatory surgical procedure under general anesthesia. The anaesthesiologist plans to use an induction agent that allows for rapid emergence post-procedure. Which of the following agent is the preferred induction agent used in day care surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Propofol

 

Option A. Propofol is a preferred induction agent in day care surgery. It offers a rapid onset of anesthesia and allows for quick emergence post-procedure. Its short duration of action and amnestic effects make it suitable for ambulatory surgical procedures.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option B. Thiopentone: Thiopentone is not typically the first choice for induction in day care surgery. While it is an ultra short-acting barbiturate, it may have a slower recovery profile compared to propofol.

 

Option C. Ketamine: Ketamine is a dissociative anaesthetic agent that can provide rapid induction and analgesia. However, it may not be the preferred choice for day care surgery due to its potential for hallucinations and psychomimetic effects during emergence.

 

Option D. Diazepam: Diazepam is not commonly used as an induction agent in day care surgery. It is more often utilized for preoperative anxiolysis and sedation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In day care surgery, the choice of induction agent is crucial for achieving rapid onset of anesthesia and ensuring quick emergence to facilitate patient recovery and discharge. Propofol is often preferred in such settings due to its favorable pharmacokinetic profile.

 

Preferable agents in Day Care AnesthesiaBottom of Form

  • Muscle Relaxant of Choice – Scoline or Rocuronium/Sugammadex combination
  • Sevoflurane (Volatile Inhalational Agent)
  • Opioid- Remifentanil
  • Propofol (inducing Agent of Choice)
  • Midazolam (for Initial Anxiolysis and Sedation)

 

 

REF: Millers Anesthesia 9th edition

choices.text: Renal Failure due to Sepsis
Respiratory Failure due to Over Sedation

questions.text: A 36-year-old female presented to emergency with cough, fever, and abdominal and back pain for one week. She had tachycardia, tachypnoea, hypotension and bilateral rales on auscultation. Chest radiographs revealed rounded densities in the right middle lung. Initial assessment of the chest radiographs signified acute respiratory failure with severe sepsis, likely secondary to pneumonia. The patient was intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation, started on vasopressors, antibiotics, propofol and midazolam for sedation. Her condition worsened and that resulted in increased doses of all sedative agents and the addition of fentanyl. 2-3 days later, she developed generalized rash over the body along with elevated Creatinine, sinus tachycardia, diastolic dysfunction and metabolic acidosis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Propofol Infusion Syndrome

 

Option D. The described clinical features, including metabolic acidosis, multiple organ failure, hemodynamic instability, hepatomegaly, and rash, are indicative of propofol infusion syndrome. This syndrome is associated with prolonged high dose propofol infusions and can lead to severe complications, including organ dysfunction and metabolic derangements.

1st sign of Propofol infusion syndrome is Abnormal levels of Lipemia

 

Explanation:

Option A. Renal Failure due to Sepsis: While sepsis can lead to Acute Kidney Injury (AKI), the clinical presentation described in the scenario, including a generalized rash, sinus tachycardia, diastolic dysfunction, and metabolic acidosis, is not primarily indicative of renal failure.

 

Option B. Fentanyl Overdose: While fentanyl is an opioid that can lead to respiratory depression when overdosed, the symptoms mentioned in the scenario, such as a generalized rash and diastolic dysfunction, are not typical of opioid overdose.

 

Option C. Respiratory Failure due to Over Sedation: Over-sedation with propofol, midazolam, and fentanyl can cause respiratory depression, but the additional symptoms like rash, diastolic dysfunction, and metabolic acidosis are not consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

Essential features of propofol infusion syndrome are metabolic acidosis, multiple organ failure, hemodynamic instability, hepatomegaly, and rhabdomyolysis. It occurs due to long term propofol infusion (> 48 hours) for sedation at high doses (>5 mg/kg/hr) leading to impaired fatty acid metabolism in the body.

 

Patients will have Green color Urine as Propofol contains Phenol.

1st sign of Propofol infusion syndrome is Abnormal levels of Lipemia

 

REF: Morgan and Mikhail’s anaesthesiology 7th edition page 338

questions.text: A patient was operated for Left upper lobe of the lung resection.2 hours after the surgery, his vitals was BP 70/50 mm of Hg. HR- 136 bpm, SPO2 92 and surgical drain was filled with blood. Immediate re-exploration was planned. IV anaesthetic agent of choice is.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ketamine

 

Option A. Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic that has the unique property of providing sedation while maintaining cardiovascular stability. It does this by stimulating the sympathetic nervous system and inhibiting the reuptake of norepinephrine, which can increase arterial pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output. This makes it an excellent choice for patients who are hemodynamically unstable, as in the case described.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Propofol: Propofol is a commonly used IV anaesthetic agent known for its rapid onset and short duration of action. However, it causes vasodilation and myocardial depression, which can lead to hypotension. Therefore, it is not the ideal choice for a patient who is already in a state of shock with low blood pressure.

 

Option C. Thiopentone: Thiopentone is a barbiturate that is also used for inducing anesthesia. Like propofol, it can cause cardiovascular depression leading to hypotension, which would not be beneficial in a patient who is already hypotensive following surgery.

 

Option D. Etomidate: Etomidate is known for its cardiovascular stability and is often used in patients at risk of hypotension. However, it does not provide any sympathetic stimulation and may not be as effective as ketamine in supporting the cardiovascular system in a shock state.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ketamine is the anaesthetic of choice in patients with severe hypotension and shock, due to its sympathetic stimulatory effects which help maintain arterial pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output.

 

 

REF: Morgan and Mikhail’s Anesthesiology 7th edition page 332-338

choices.text: Most commonly used drug is Propofol
It reduces Cerebral Blood Flow and Intracranial Pressure
It leads to Increased Incidence of Post-Operative Nausea and Vomiting

questions.text: Which of these is not true regarding Total Intravenous Anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. It leads to Increased Incidence of Post-Operative Nausea and Vomiting

 

Option D. This statement is not true regarding TIVA when using Propofol. In fact, TIVA with Propofol is associated with a lower incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) compared to inhalational anesthesia, which is one of the reasons it is preferred for patients who are at a high risk of PONV.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option A. Most commonly used drug is Propofol: This is true. Propofol is the most frequently used agent for TIVA due to its rapid onset and recovery profile, along with its favourable side-effect profile when compared to inhalational agents.

 

Option B. It causes Smooth Induction: True. One of the advantages of Propofol is that it allows for a smooth induction of anesthesia, which is less stimulating compared to other agents and is generally well-tolerated by patients.

 

Option C. It reduces Cerebral Blood Flow and Intracranial Pressure: True. Propofol decreases cerebral blood flow and consequently reduces intracranial pressure, which is beneficial in patients with brain pathologies and during neurosurgical procedures.

 

Educational objective:

 

In Total Intravenous Anesthesia

IV Anesthetic of Choice – Propofol

Opioid Analgesic of Choice - Remifentanil

 

 

REF: Miller's Anesthesia 8th edition • Page no: 919

questions.text: Which intravenous induction agent suppresses airway reflexes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Propofol

 

Option B.

 

  • Propofol is an intravenous induction agent known for its ability to suppress upper airway reflexes to a significant extent.
  • It is commonly used for procedures such as intubation, endoscopy, and laryngeal mask placement, where suppression of airway reflexes is essential for patient comfort and safety.
  • Propofol allows for smooth and controlled airway management without the need for additional muscle relaxants.

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s evaluate each option:

 

Option A. Thiopentone:

 

  • Thiopentone is a barbiturate that is used for induction of anesthesia.
  • Unlike some other induction agents, thiopentone tends to stimulate airway reflexes rather than suppress them. It can lead to coughing and laryngospasm, making it less preferred for procedures involving airway manipulation.

 

Option C. Etomidate:

 

  • Etomidate is another intravenous induction agent that is known for its relatively minimal effects on airway reflexes.
  • While it may not suppress airway reflexes as profoundly as propofol, it is still considered suitable for procedures that require airway manipulation with minimal risk of reflex-mediated complications.

 

Option D. Ketamine:

 

  • Ketamine is unique among intravenous induction agents because it tends to preserve upper airway reflexes and maintain upper airway muscle tone.
  • While it may not suppress airway reflexes like propofol, ketamine's profile can be advantageous in certain clinical situations where preserving airway reflexes is desired.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the intravenous induction agents commonly used in anesthesia, propofol is the one that suppresses airway reflexes to the maximum extent. This property makes it a preferred choice for procedures involving airway manipulation, as it allows for intubation, endoscopy, or laryngeal mask placement without the need for additional muscle relaxants.

 

 

REF: Stoelting’s Pharmacology in Anesthesia pg. 162-192

questions.text: Local anaesthetics have greatest affinity for which type of sodium channels?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inactivated

 

Option B.

 

  • Sodium channels in the inactivated state are a preferred target for local anesthetics.
  • Local anesthetics have the greatest affinity for sodium channels when they are in this state, which occurs shortly after the channel has been activated and has closed in response to the depolarization of the cell membrane.
  • Binding to inactivated sodium channels prevents them from reopening, thus inhibiting the generation and propagation of action potentials.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Activated:

 

  • Sodium channels can exist in an activated state when they are open, allowing the influx of sodium ions during an action potential.
  • Local anesthetics do interact with sodium channels, but their binding affinity is not highest when the channels are in the activated state.

 

Option C. Resting:

 

  • Sodium channels in the resting state (closed) are not the primary target for local anesthetics.
  • These channels are not actively involved in the generation of action potentials, and local anesthetics are more effective at blocking channels in the inactivated state.

 

Option D. Open:

 

  • Sodium channels in the open state allow the flow of sodium ions, and they are not the primary target for local anesthetics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Local anesthetics exert their effects by blocking sodium channels in the inactivated state. This is a crucial mechanism of action as it prevents the generation and propagation of action potentials in neurons, leading to the loss of sensation in the region where the local anesthetic is applied.

 

 

Local anaesthetics have maximum affinity for Na+ channels in inactivated state as compared to resting or open state. They bind to the Na+ channels from inside and block them due to which the action potential cannot be generated, and impulse cannot be propagated.

 

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 9th edition pg 866

questions.text: Methemoglobinemia is associated with which local anaesthetic drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Prilocaine

 

Methemoglobinemia is associated with certain local anesthetic drugs, and one of those drugs is:

 

Option B.

 

  • Prilocaine is a local anesthetic commonly used for various medical and dental procedures.
  • One of its potential side effects is the development of methemoglobinemia.
  • Methemoglobinemia is a condition where hemoglobin in the blood is oxidized and unable to carry oxygen effectively, leading to reduced oxygen delivery to tissues.

 

Explanation:

 

Additional Information:

 

  • Articaine and benzocaine are also local anesthetics that can cause methemoglobinemia.
  • Methemoglobinemia can lead to symptoms such as cyanosis (bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes), shortness of breath, dizziness, and altered mental status.
  • Treatment of methemoglobinemia often involves administering methylene blue, which helps convert methemoglobin back to its normal, oxygen-carrying form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methemoglobinemia is a rare but serious side effect associated with certain local anesthetic drugs, including prilocaine, articaine, and benzocaine.

 

METHEMOGLOBINEMIA

 

It is characterized by

 

  • Reduced haemoglobin >1 g/dL in RBCs.
  • Blood turns chocolate-brown in colour
  • Postmortem Lividity – Chocolate brown

 

Causes –

 

  • Prilocaine, Benzocaine
  • Nitrates/Nitrites
  • Aniline
  • Dapsone, Sulfonamides

 

Treatment –

 

  • DOC – I.V Methylene Blue
  • Vitamin C can be used as an ancillary treatment.

 

Important information about local anesthestics:-

 

  • Chlorprocaine is the shortest acting LA.
  • Dibucaine is the longest acting, most potent and most toxic LA.
  • Bupivacaine is the most cardiotoxic LA
  • Levobupivacaine (the S (-) enantiomer of bupivacaine) is less cardiotoxic and less prone to cause seizure.
  • Lignocaine is the most commonly used LA.
  • Chlorprocaine is contraindicated in spinal anaesthesia as it can cause paraplegia due to presence of neurotoxic preservative sodium metabisulphite.
  • Procaine is the LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anaesthesiology 7th edition pg 491

choices.text: Sodium Channel Blockade
Potassium Channel Blockade
Calcium Channel Blockade

questions.text: Which of these is the main action of local anaesthetics?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sodium Channel Blockade

 

Option A.

 

  • The primary mechanism of action of local anesthetics is the blockade of voltage-gated sodium channels in nerves.
  • By blocking these sodium channels, local anesthetics prevent the influx of sodium ions and the generation of action potentials in nerve fibers, leading to reversible loss of sensation in the affected area.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. NMDA Antagonism:

 

  • While local anesthetics primarily act on sodium channels, some may have additional actions, such as NMDA receptor antagonism.
  • NMDA receptors are involved in the perception of pain and the transmission of pain signals in the central nervous system.
  • NMDA antagonism may contribute to the analgesic effects of certain local anesthetics.

 

Option C. Potassium Channel Blockade:

 

  • Local anesthetics do not typically block potassium channels as their primary mode of action. The primary target is sodium channels.

 

Option D. Calcium Channel Blockade:

 

  • Local anesthetics do not primarily block calcium channels. They primarily target sodium channels to achieve their anesthetic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

The main action of local anesthetics is the blockade of voltage-gated sodium channels in nerves. This blockade prevents the generation and propagation of action potentials, resulting in reversible loss of sensation in the affected area. While some local anesthetics may have additional actions, such as NMDA antagonism, their primary mechanism of action is sodium channel blockade.

 

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia 8th edition page 1038

questions.text: All of the following local anesthetics are metabolized in the plasma except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cocaine

 

Option B.

 

  • Cocaine is a unique local anesthetic in that it is primarily metabolized (ester hydrolysis) in the liver, not in the plasma.
  • Liver enzymes, particularly carboxylesterases, play a crucial role in the metabolism of cocaine into various metabolites.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Procaine:

 

  • Procaine is an ester local anesthetic that is primarily metabolized by pseudocholinesterase (also known as butyrylcholinesterase) in the plasma.
  • Ester hydrolysis of procaine occurs rapidly, leading to the formation of water-soluble metabolites that are excreted in the urine.

 

Option C. Tetracaine:

 

  • Tetracaine is another local anesthetic that is metabolized by pseudocholinesterase in the plasma, similar to procaine.
  • Ester hydrolysis of tetracaine leads to the formation of metabolites that are excreted in the urine.

 

Option D. Benzocaine:

 

  • Benzocaine, like procaine, is an ester local anesthetic that is metabolized by pseudocholinesterase in the plasma.
  • Ester hydrolysis of benzocaine results in the formation of p-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) as a metabolite, which has been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Local anesthetics can be categorized into ester and amide types, and their metabolism varies between these categories. Ester local anesthetics, such as procaine, tetracaine, and benzocaine, are predominantly metabolized by pseudocholinesterase in the plasma, with rapid ester hydrolysis leading to water-soluble metabolites excreted in the urine. Ester hydrolysis is rapid, and the water-soluble metabolites are excreted in the urine.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th edition pg 269 Morgan 7th 490

choices.text: Local Infiltration Anaesthesia

questions.text: Identify the block given in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bier’s Block

 

Explanation:

 

Option D. Bier's Block

 

Bier's block, also known as Intravenous Regional Anesthesia, is a technique used to provide surgical anesthesia for relatively short and superficial surgical procedures on an extremity, such as carpal tunnel release. The key features of Bier's block include the use of an intravenous catheter inserted into the dorsum of the hand (or foot) and the application of a double pneumatic tourniquet on the forearm, arm, below the knee, or on the thigh. Local anesthetic is then injected through the intravenous line into the isolated extremity.

 

  • Lidocaine is commonly used as the local anesthetic agent for intravenous regional anesthesia (Bier's block).
  • Bupivacaine and Ropivacaine are contraindicated for use in Bier's block due to the potential for cardiac toxicity with these agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bier's block, also known as intravenous regional anesthesia, is a technique used for providing surgical anesthesia for short and superficial procedures on an extremity. This method involves the insertion of an intravenous catheter, application of a pneumatic tourniquet, and the administration of a local anesthetic into the isolated extremity.

 

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th edition pg 269 Morgan 7th 1906

choices.text: Increased Distribution of LA
Decreased Absorption of LA
Decreased Duration of LA
Increased Metabolism of LA

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is posted for lower limb debridement surgery under femoral and sciatic block. The drug used for blockade is 2% lignocaine with adrenaline. Addition of adrenaline to local anesthetic causes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Decreased Absorption of LA

 

Explanation:

 

The addition of adrenaline (epinephrine) to a local anesthetic causes the following effect:

 

Option B.

 

  • Adrenaline, when added to a local anesthetic solution, acts as a vasoconstrictor.
  • Vasoconstrictors like adrenaline reduce the blood flow to the area where the local anesthetic is injected.
  • This decreased blood flow results in reduced absorption of the local anesthetic into the bloodstream, as it limits the rate at which the drug enters the systemic circulation.
  • As a result, the presence of adrenaline in the local anesthetic solution prolongs the duration of action and provides a more profound block, making the anesthesia more effective and longer lasting.
  • This vasoconstrictor action of adrenaline is particularly useful in regional anesthesia techniques like femoral and sciatic blocks, where it helps improve the depth and duration of anesthesia.
  • Vasoconstrictors should be used cautiously and are contraindicated in specific situations, such as injections close to end arteries (e.g., ring blocks of finger and toe digits), intravenous regional anesthesia (Bier's block)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The addition of adrenaline to a local anesthetic solution serves as a vasoconstrictor, leading to decreased absorption of the local anesthetic into the bloodstream.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th edition pg 269 Morgan 7th 489

questions.text:
Which statement(s) is/are accurate concerning local anesthetics?

 

  1. Prilocaine is Longer Acting than Bupivacaine.
  2. Tetracaine is more Potent than Lignocaine.
  3. Dibucaine is the Longest Acting Local Anesthetic.
  4. Bupivacaine can produce Cardiotoxicity.
  5. Cocaine can produce Hypotension.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2,3,4

 

Explanation:

 

  • Prilocaine is Longer Acting than Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is known for its long duration of action, while prilocaine has a shorter duration of action compared to bupivacaine. Therefore, this statement is false.
  • Tetracaine is more Potent than Lignocaine: Tetracaine is considered a high-potency local anesthetic and is generally more potent than lignocaine (lidocaine), which is an intermediate-potency local anesthetic.
  • Dibucaine is the Longest-Acting Local Anesthetic: Dibucaine is known for its very long duration of action among local anesthetics, making it one of the longest-acting agents in this class.
  • Bupivacaine can produce Cardiotoxicity: Bupivacaine, particularly when used in high doses or inadvertently administered systemically, can produce cardiotoxicity, including potential for cardiac arrhythmias and toxicity.
  • Cocaine can produce Hypotension: Cocaine, as a vasoconstrictor, can lead to hypertension rather than hypotension due to its effects on the cardiovascular system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on potency & duration local anaesthetics are classified into:

 

 

  • Cocaine causes vasoconstriction leading to hypertension.
  • Bupivacaine is the most cardiotoxic local anesthetic.

 

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 8th edition pg 1031

questions.text: A first year anesthesia resident is giving axillary block by landmark guided technique. She accidentally punctures the axillary artery during the process and injects 20 ml of local anesthetic intravascularly. The patient starts getting seizures bradyarrythmias and severe hypotension within 5 minutes of this injection. What should be the treatment of this condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 20% Intralipid

 

  • This is a case of Local Anesthesia Systemic Toxicity (LAST).
  • Drug of choice for treatment of Local Anesthesia Systemic Toxicity is 20% Lipid emulsion therapy at 1.5ml/kg.

 

Option C. 20% Intralipid is the drug of choice for treating LAST. It works by creating a lipid sink, where the lipophilic local anesthetic molecules are sequestered in the lipid phase, reducing their toxic effects. This can rapidly reverse the symptoms of LAST, including seizures, bradyarrhythmias, and hypotension.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dantrolene Sodium: Dantrolene Sodium is a medication used to treat malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option B. 10% Intralipid: Intralipid, a Lipid Emulsion, is used to treat LAST. However, 10% Intralipid is less concentrated than 20% Intralipid and may be less effective in rapidly reversing the toxic effects of intravascular local anesthetic injection.

 

Option D. Vasopressin: Vasopressin can help in treating hypotension, but it has no role in LAST.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Local Anesthesia Systemic Toxicity (LAST) can occur when local anesthetics are inadvertently injected intravascularly. The most effective treatment for LAST is the administration of 20% Intralipid, a lipid emulsion, which acts as a lipid sink to sequester and reduce the toxic effects of local anesthetics. Early recognition and prompt administration of 20% Intralipid can reverse the symptoms of LAST and prevent serious complications.

 

Drug of choice - 20% Lipid emulsion therapy at 1.5ml/kg

 

 

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 8th edition • Page no: 1048-1050

questions.text: An ophthalmologist wants to examine a 10-year-old child with an irritating sensation in the eye. Which of these is local anesthetics is commonly used as a part of topical ophthalmic eye drops?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Proparacaine

 

Option A:

 

  • Proparacaine is a topical ophthalmic anesthetic agent commonly used by ophthalmologists for procedures such as eye examinations, foreign body removal, or minor eye surgeries.
  • It has a rapid onset of action, typically within 2 minutes, and provides effective local anesthesia for approximately 20 minutes, making it suitable for short ophthalmic procedures.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Option B. Cocaine: Cocaine is an older anesthetic agent and is not commonly used in modern ophthalmology due to its potential for abuse and addiction.

 

Option C. Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic commonly used for regional anesthesia and nerve blocks, but it is not typically used as a topical ophthalmic anesthetic.

 

Option D. Mepivacaine: Mepivacaine is another local anesthetic primarily used for dental and regional anesthesia and is not commonly used in ophthalmic applications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proparacaine (0.5%) and Tetracaine (0.5%) are commonly used topical ophthalmic anesthetic agents for providing short-term local anesthesia during eye examinations or minor eye procedures. Ophthalmologists often use these agents to ensure patient comfort during these procedures.

 

Commonly used eye drops in ophthalmic solutions is:

 

Proparacaine (0.5%) and Tetracaine (0.5%)
Duration of action of Proparacaine is 20 minutes. Onset of its action is within 2 minutes.

 

 

Ref: Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition • Page no 413

choices.text: Persistent Depolarization at Neuromuscular Junction
Persistent Depolarization at the Ach Receptors
Competitively Blocking the binding of ACh to its Receptors
Inhibiting the Calcium Channel on the Neuronal Membrane

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers like the curare group of muscle relaxants?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Competitively Blocking the binding of ACh to its Receptors

 

Option C. Non-Depolarizing Neuromuscular Blockers like curare derivatives (e.g., Tubocurarine, Pancuronium, Rocuronium, Vecuronium) act by competitively binding to the nicotinic acetylcholine (ACh) receptors at the neuromuscular junction. These drugs effectively block the binding of acetylcholine to its receptors, preventing the activation of muscle fibers by acetylcholine. As a result, they inhibit the transmission of nerve impulses from motor neurons to muscle fibers, leading to muscle relaxation and paralysis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Persistent Depolarization at Neuromuscular Junction: is not the correct mechanism. Non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers do not cause persistent depolarization; instead, they block the depolarization initiated by acetylcholine.

 

Option B. Persistent Depolarization at the ACh Receptors: is not accurate. These drugs do not cause persistent depolarization; they prevent depolarization by inhibiting ACh binding.

 

Option D. Inhibiting the Calcium Channel on the Neuronal Membrane: is not the mechanism of action for non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers. These drugs do not directly affect calcium channels.

 

Educational objective:

 

Non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers competitively block the binding of acetylcholine to its receptors, leading to muscle relaxation and paralysis, and are essential in anesthesia and critical care for various medical procedures.

 

Ref: Millers anesthesia 8th edition page 959-965

choices.text: Spinal Cord Injury
Guillain Barre Syndrome
All of the above

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is posted for emergency exploratory laparotomy; the anaesthetist wants to perform rapid sequence intubation. Succinylcholine can be used in all of the following patients except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

Option D. Succinylcholine should be avoided in all of the mentioned conditions (burns, spinal cord injury, Guillain-Barre syndrome, etc.) as they can potentially lead to life-threatening hyperkalemia when succinylcholine is administered.

 

Explanation:

Option A. Burns Patient: Burns can lead to an increased release of potassium from damaged cells, potentially causing Hyperkalemia. Succinylcholine, a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker, can further elevate potassium levels and should be avoided in burn patients to prevent life-threatening Hyperkalemia.

 

Option B. Spinal Cord Injury: Patients with spinal cord injuries may have altered regulation of potassium due to impaired neural control. Succinylcholine administration can lead to uncontrolled potassium release and severe Hyperkalemia in these patients.

 

Option C. Guillain-Barre Syndrome: Guillain-Barre syndrome is a neurological disorder that can affect the peripheral nervous system. Patients with this condition may already have altered neuromuscular transmission, and succinylcholine can exacerbate the risk of Hyperkalemia.

 

Educational objective:

 

Succinylcholine in certain conditions can cause life-threatening Hyperkalemia. These conditions are:

  • Burns
  • Spinal cord injury
  • Old stroke
  • Tetanus
  • Prolonged immobilization
  • Myopathies
  • Guillain-Barre syndrome
  • Malignant hyperthermia history

 

Note - Pre-existing Hyperkalemia conditions like A) Chronic Renal Failure B) Head Injury C) Advanced liver failure/sepsis due to decreases concentration of Pseudocholine-esterase D) Duchene Muscle dystrophy/Dystrophia myotonica E) Avoid in the new-born (extra-junctional receptors which increase the K+ level).

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anaesthesiology 5th edition pg 210

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is posted for emergency exploratory laparotomy; the anaesthetist wants to perform rapid sequence intubation. What would be the muscle relaxant of choice for rapid sequence intubation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Succinylcholine

 

Explanation:

 

Muscle relaxant of choice for rapid sequence intubation is Succinylcholine is due to:

  • Rapid onset of action
  • Shortest acting muscle relaxant

 

In case of contraindication to succinylcholine – drug of choice for RSI – Rocuronium

 

Educational Objective 

The muscle relaxant of choice for rapid sequence intubation is Succinylcholine

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 8th ed pg 1020

choices.text: Posterior Tibial Nerve

questions.text: While giving non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockade which nerve is commonly used for monitoring the intensity of the blockade?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ulnar Nerve

 

Option B.

 

  • This is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade. The ulnar nerve is easily accessible, and the response of the adductor pollicis muscle (thumb adduction) it innervates can be easily observed or measured using a peripheral nerve stimulator.
  • Neuromuscular function monitoring is an essential technique in anesthesia to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade provided by non-depolarizing muscle relaxants.
  • The ulnar nerve is preferred for monitoring because the hand muscles it innervates, especially the adductor pollicis, provide a clear, measurable response to stimulation, which is essential for accurate monitoring of neuromuscular blockade and ensuring complete recovery from muscle relaxants before extubation and recovery.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Posterior Tibial Nerve: While this nerve can be used for monitoring, it is less commonly chosen because of its location and the bulkier muscles it innervates, which might not be as accessible during many surgical procedures.

 

Option C. Radial Nerve: Less commonly used for standard monitoring, as its primary innervated muscles in the arm and back of the hand are not as responsive for assessing subtle degrees of neuromuscular blockade compared to the muscles innervated by the ulnar nerve.

 

Option D. Facial Nerve: Although the facial nerve can be used, especially during head and neck surgeries, it's less common for general procedures. The facial expressions caused by its stimulation can be more subjective and less quantifiable compared to the hand's muscle responses to ulnar nerve stimulation.

 

Educational Objective 

Ulnar nerve is the most commonly used nerve for monitoring neuromuscular blockade

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 8th edition pg 1610

choices.text: Phase I block
Phase II block
Phase III block
Phase IV block

questions.text: Desensitization of Acetylcholine receptors after giving a large dose or continuous bolus doses of succinylcholine, resulting in prolonged neuromuscular blockade is called as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Phase II Block

 

Explanation:

 

Succinylcholine, also known as suxamethonium, is a depolarizing muscle relaxant that can produce two types of neuromuscular blocks, Phase I and Phase II, which has distinct characteristics:

 

Phase I Block:

 

  • Rapid Onset: Succinylcholine acts quickly, causing depolarization of the muscle endplate shortly after administration.
  • Persistent Depolarization: It continuously stimulates the nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction, causing persistent depolarization and resulting in muscle paralysis.
  • Depolarization Block Features: This includes sustained muscle fasciculations followed by flaccid paralysis.
  • Anticholinesterase Resistance: The block cannot be reversed by anticholinesterase drugs like neostigmine because these drugs increase the amount of acetylcholine, which is ineffective once the receptor is depolarized and desensitized.

 

Phase II Block (Dual Block):

 

  • Slow Onset: With prolonged exposure to succinylcholine or after repeated doses, the receptor becomes desensitized, leading to a slower onset of blockade.
  • Desensitization of Receptors: The acetylcholine receptors become unresponsive to acetylcholine, which is similar to the mechanism seen with non-depolarizing (competitive) blockers.
  • Similarity to Non-Depolarizing Block: The characteristics of Phase II block are akin to those produced by competitive blockers, and the block can be partially reversed by anticholinesterase drugs.
  • Conditions for Occurrence: Phase II block is more likely to be seen when large doses of succinylcholine are used, with the administration of certain anesthetics like fluorinated anesthetics, or in patients with atypical or deficient pseudocholinesterase, which slows the breakdown of succinylcholine.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical Anesthesiology 5th edition pg 210

choices.text: Post Tetanic Facilitation and Fade Absent
Train of Four Ratio > 0.4 but no Fade
Block is Reversed by Neostigmine
Fasciculation & Block potentiated by Volatile Anaesthetic Agents

questions.text: Which of the following statements about depolarizing neuromuscular blockade produced by succinylcholine is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Block is Reversed by Neostigmine

 

Option C. This statement is false. Succinylcholine-induced block is not reversed by neostigmine. Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, which is effective for reversing non-depolarizing (competitive) blocks but not depolarizing blocks.

 

Explanation:

 

Depolarizing neuromuscular blockade produced by succinylcholine has unique characteristics:

 

Option A. Post-Tetanic Facilitation and Fade Absent: In depolarizing blockade, post-tetanic potentiation or facilitation and fade are typically absent because the mechanism of blockade is persistent depolarization, not receptor competition or presynaptic inhibition of acetylcholine release.

 

Option B. Train of Four Ratio > 0.4 but No Fade: With succinylcholine-induced depolarizing blockade, the train of four (TOF) ratio can be greater than 0.4 without fade because the block is characterized by a persistent depolarization of the neuromuscular endplate, not an interference with acetylcholine binding as seen with non-depolarizing blockers.

 

Option D. Fasciculation & Block Potentiated by Volatile Anesthetic Agents: Volatile anesthetics are known to potentiate the effects of succinylcholine, leading to more pronounced fasciculations and a deeper neuromuscular block.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs undergoes Hoffman elimination?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Atracurium

 

Explanation:

 

Atracurium Pharmacokinetics:

 

  • Dose: 0.5 mg/kg
  • Onset of action: 2–3 minutes;
  • Duration of action: 10–15 minutes

 

Metabolism

 

  • It undergoes spontaneous degradation in plasma through Hoffman degradation, which is independent of hepatic & renal functions.

 

Systemic Effects

 

  • Histamine release causes flushing, hypotension, and bronchospasm.
  • CNS: At higher doses, it is metabolized to laudanosine, which can cross blood brain barrier & produce convulsions.
  • Allergic reactions can occur.
  • It is the muscle relaxant of choice in the following groups of patients because its metabolism is independent of renal and liver functions.
    1. Hepatic failure
    2. Renal failure
    3. If reversal agent is contraindicated, e.g., Myasthenia gravis
    4. New-borns
    5. Old age

 

Educational objective:

 

Atracurium is metabolized by Hoffman elimination, an organ-independent process, making it suitable for use in patients with hepatic or renal failure, as well as in myasthenia gravis, neonates, and the elderly. It has an onset of 2-3 minutes, a short duration of action, but can cause histamine release and, at high doses, produce CNS effects due to laudanosine.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7th edition pg 394

questions.text: Most common drug causing allergy in immediate perioperative period is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Antibiotics > Muscle relaxants

 

Explanation:

 

Antibiotics are now the most common cause of anaphylaxis in immediate peri-operative period.

 

  • Antibiotics > Muscle relaxants are most common cause of anaphylaxis during anesthesia.
  • Among muscle relaxants, Succinylcholine induces mast cell degranulation by crosslinking IgE receptors on mast cells.
  • Succinylcholine is more likely to cause anaphylaxis than nondepolarizing muscle relaxants.
  • Anaphylaxis may develop even on the first exposure to a muscle relaxant since they may already be sensitized to quaternary ammonium compounds present in products of daily use.
  • Neostigmine & Morphine also can cause anaphylaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

Antibiotics, particularly beta-lactams, are the most common cause of immediate perioperative anaphylaxis, followed by neuromuscular blockers due to the presence of ammonium ions which are allergenic.

Antibiotics>Neuromuscular Blockers> Chlorhexidine>Local Anaesthetic> Latex

 

Ref: https://resources.wfsahq.org/atotw/an-update-on-perioperative anaphylaxis/#:~:text=Risk%20factors%20for%20anaphylaxis%20include,lactam%20antibiotics)%2C%20and%20latex.

questions.text: Shortest acting non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mivacurium

 

Explanation:

 

Muscle Relaxants

Mivacurium is the only non-depolarizing blocker that is metabolized by plasma cholinesterase and is the shortest-acting muscle relaxant.

 

 

Educational Objective 

Long Acting: Pancuronium, Pipecuronium

Intermediate Acting: Atracurium,Cisatracurium.Vecuronium,Rocuronium

Short acting: Mivacurium Ultra-short acting: Gantacurium

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s clinical anesthesiology 7th edition pg 366-406

questions.text: A 3-month-old child is undergoing surgical repair of umbilical hernia under general anesthesia. Identify the procedure performed in the picture below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Caudal Anaesthesia

 

Option A: Caudal anesthesia is a common regional anesthetic technique used in children for surgeries below the umbilicus. The procedure involves inserting a needle through the sacral hiatus to access the epidural space at the caudal end of the spinal column. This matches the procedure depicted in the image, where the landmarks of the sacral cornua are used to guide needle insertion.

 

The above image shows a caudal block which is a type of central neuraxial block, most commonly used in pediatrics to provide analgesia for surgeries up to the umbilicus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Spinal anesthesia involves the injection of anesthetic into the subarachnoid space and is typically performed at higher levels of the spine, not at the sacral hiatus. Spinal anesthesia is not commonly used in infants due to the risks associated with administering a spinal block at such a young age.

 

Option C. Similar to caudal anesthesia, Epidural anesthesia technique involves the injection of anesthetic into the epidural space, but it is usually performed at higher vertebral levels. While the caudal block is a type of epidural anesthesia, the term "epidural anesthesia" alone usually refers to lumbar or thoracic epidural injections.

 

Option D. Saddle anesthesia is a specific type of spinal anesthesia that affects only the lower extremities and perineal area, resembling the area where a saddle would be. This type of block is not depicted in the image, as it would not be performed in the sacral area for an umbilical hernia repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caudal anesthesia is a form of regional anesthesia used primarily in the pediatric population for procedures below the umbilicus, utilizing the sacral hiatus as the entry point for the anesthetic. It is commonly used due to its safety and effectiveness for sub-umbilical surgical procedures in children.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhails Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1840

choices.text: Sphenopalatine Nerve Block

questions.text: Which of these should not be used for the treatment of Postdural Puncture Headache?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Standing Position.

 

Option A: Standing or sitting in an upright position is not recommended for the treatment of Post-Dural Puncture Headache (PDPH). This position may worsen the headache due to the effect of gravity, which can exacerbate the leakage of Cerebro-Spinal Fluid (CSF) through the puncture site, leading to further lowering of CSF pressure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Administration of Intravenous (IV) fluids is part of the conservative treatment for PDPH. It helps to maintain hydration and can support the production of CSF, potentially aiding in the resolution of the headache.

 

Option C. Sphenopalatine nerve block is an interventional treatment option for PDPH where a local anesthetic is applied to the sphenopalatine ganglion via the nasal mucosa. It can help relieve the headache by blocking the associated nerve pathway.

 

Option D. Stool softeners are recommended to avoid straining during bowel movements, which can increase intracranial pressure and potentially worsen a PDPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standing position should be avoided in the treatment of PDPH because it can exacerbate the leakage of CSF and worsen the headache. Conservative treatment typically includes recumbent positioning, analgesics, hydration, and caffeine. Additional interventions like sphenopalatine ganglion block or the use of stool softeners can also be beneficial.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1850

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Identify the use of this Needle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epidural Anesthesia

 

Option B. The Tuohy Needle, characterized by its curved, blunt tip, is specifically designed to administer epidural anesthesia by threading a catheter through it into the epidural space without piercing the dura mater. The blunt, curved tip theoretically helps to push away the dura after passing through the ligamentum flavum instead of penetrating it.

 

This is Tuohy’s needle used for Epidural Anesthesia. Another classic identification feature of Tuohy needle is alternate light and dark markings on needle as shown in the image

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The design with a curved tip is not typical for spinal needles, which are usually smaller in gauge and have a sharper point.

 

Option C. While lumbar punctures do require a needle to access the subarachnoid space, the Tuohy needle is not typically used for this procedure because its design is meant to reduce the risk of dural puncture, which is necessary for obtaining cerebrospinal fluid during a lumbar puncture.

 

Option D. All of the above. Although needles are used in all the listed procedures, the Tuohy needle is specifically designed for epidural anesthesia and not typically used for spinal anesthesia or lumbar puncture.

 

Educational Objective:

The Tuohy needle, recognized for its curved,blunt tip, Alternate light and dark markings on needle, is primarily used for the administration of epidural anesthesia and is designed to minimize the risk of dural puncture.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1834

questions.text: What is the Gold Standard for management of PDPH?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epidural Blood Patch

 

Option D. The Epidural Blood Patch is indeed the gold standard treatment for PDPH. It involves the injection of autologous blood into the epidural space to form a clot, which seals the dural puncture and stops CSF leakage.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While rest is a part of the conservative management for postdural puncture headache (PDPH), it is not the gold standard treatment. Rest can help alleviate symptoms but does not address the underlying cause of the CSF leak.

 

Option B. Hydration is also a supportive measure to help with PDPH by potentially increasing CSF production, but it is not the definitive treatment for the condition.

 

Option C. Cerebral vasoconstriction caffeine and NSAIDs. These medications can provide symptomatic relief for PDPH by causing cerebral vasoconstriction and reducing pain. However, they are not considered the gold standard treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epidural blood patch is the gold standard for the management of postdural puncture headache, as it directly addresses the cause of the headache by sealing the dural puncture site and stopping CSF leakage.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhails Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1850

choices.text: Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity
Total Spinal Anesthesia
High Spinal Anesthesia

questions.text: A 25-year-old Primigravida is given 15 ml of 0.25% Heavy Bupivacaine for Lower Segment Caesarean Section (LSCS) in the Epidural Space. She developed Hypotension, Respiratory Arrest and became unconscious within 2minutes, what could be the cause for the same?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total Spinal Anesthesia

 

Option B: If Local Anesthetic is inadvertently injected into the Cerebrospinal Fluid during an attempt at Epidural Anesthesia, it can lead to a blockade of the entire Spinal Cord and Brainstem, resulting in Hypotension, Respiratory Arrest, and loss of Consciousness, as described in the scenario.

 

Intracranial Spread of Local Anesthetic is called as Total Spinal Anesthesia. It is characterized by symptoms like Slurred Speech, Sedation and loss of Consciousness. lt can occur following Epidural Anaesthesia/Analgesia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Local anesthetic systemic toxicity - This condition occurs when a high plasma level of local anesthetic affects the central nervous system and cardiovascular system, leading to symptoms such as seizures, cardiac arrhythmias, and even cardiac arrest. However, the rapid onset of unconsciousness and respiratory arrest described in the question is less typical for systemic toxicity, which usually presents with CNS excitation before depression.

 

Option C. High spinal anesthesia occurs when local anesthetic is injected into the subarachnoid space and affects a large portion of the spinal cord, potentially leading to extensive sympathetic blockade and paralysis of the chest and upper abdominal muscles. While it can cause severe Hypotension and Respiratory difficulty, the rapid progression to unconsciousness is more indicative of a total spinal.

 

Option D. An allergic reaction to drugs can cause symptoms such as rash, itching, swelling, and in severe cases, anaphylaxis. Respiratory arrest and unconsciousness are possible but would typically be accompanied by other signs of allergy, which are not described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total spinal anesthesia refers to the inadvertent spread of local anesthetic to the cranial subarachnoid space during epidural anesthesia, leading to severe hypotension, respiratory arrest, and loss of consciousness. Management includes airway support, oxygen, vasopressors, and intravenous fluids.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1848

choices.text: Requirement of Local Anesthetic Drug is Increased.
There is an Increase in Cardiac Output.
There is a Decrease in Venous Return.
Hypotension is uncommon.

questions.text: Which of these statements about Epidural Anesthesia in Pregnancy is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) There is a Decrease in Venous Return.

 

Option C: Correct. In pregnant patients, the enlarging uterus can compress the inferior vena cava when the patient is in the supine position, leading to decreased venous return. This effect can be exacerbated by the vasodilation caused by epidural anesthesia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. During pregnancy, particularly in the context of epidural anesthesia, there is actually a decreased requirement for local anesthetic drugs due to physiological changes, such as increased sensitivity to local anesthetics and the distension of the epidural venous plexus.

 

Option B. Incorrect. Cardiac output may decrease during epidural anesthesia in pregnancy due to a reduction in venous return, especially if hypotension occurs as a side effect.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Hypotension is actually a common side effect of epidural anesthesia, particularly in pregnant patients due to the combined effects of the anesthesia and the physiological changes of pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant patients receiving epidural anesthesia, there is typically a decreased requirement for local anesthetic drugs and a common occurrence of hypotension, often due to a decrease in venous return from the compression of the inferior vena cava by the enlarging uterus.

 

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Page 1570

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Neuraxial Anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bier’s Block

 

Option C: Incorrect. Bier’s block, or Intra-Venous Regional Anesthesia (IVRA), is not a form of neuraxial anesthesia. It is used for surgical procedures on extremities, such as the forearm or leg, where a tourniquet is applied, and anesthetic is injected into a vein.

 

BIER’S BLOCK:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Correct. Spinal anesthesia is a form of neuraxial anesthesia where local anesthetic is injected into the cerebrospinal fluid in the subarachnoid space.

 

Option B. Correct. Epidural anesthesia is another form of neuraxial anesthesia involving the injection of anesthetic in the epidural space.

 

Option D. Correct. Caudal anesthesia is a type of neuraxial block where the anesthetic is injected near the sacral hiatus and is often used in pediatric anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neuraxial anesthesia includes procedures such as spinal, epidural, and caudal anesthesia, where local anesthetics are placed around the central nervous system nerves. Bier’s block is not a form of neuraxial anesthesia as it is used for peripheral regional anesthesia of the extremities.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Pg 1784

questions.text: The anesthesiologist is administering a brachial plexus block by landmark guided technique. He gives 0.5% bupivacaine 20ml. After 10 minutes, the patient starts complaining of peri-oral numbness and starts getting seizures. What would be the treatment of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20% Intralipid

 

Option B: Correct. The 20% Intralipid solution is the treatment of choice for LAST. It acts by creating a lipid sink, which helps to absorb and neutralize the local anesthetic in the bloodstream, reducing its toxicity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incorrect. While Intralipid can be used to treat local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), the 10% solution is not the standard concentration recommended for the initial management of LAST.

 

Option C. Incorrect. Dantrolene sodium is used to treat Malignant Hyperthermia, a different condition that is triggered by certain anesthetics and Muscle Relaxants, not LAST.

 

Option D. Incorrect. Bromocriptine is a medication used to treat conditions such as Parkinson's disease and hyperprolactinemia, and it does not have a role in the management of LAST.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) is intravenous 20% Intralipid. This condition is characterized by initial excitatory symptoms followed by depressive cardiovascular symptoms and can be life-threatening if not promptly managed.

 

Ref: Millers Anesthesia 8th Edition Page no: 1047, 1715

choices.text: Cuffed Endotracheal Tube is not preferred due to chance of Tracheal Stenosis
Depth of Chest Compressions is equal to A-P diameter
First Shock Energy to be delivered is 3 J/kg
In Infants after Intubation Respiratory Rate should be 20-30 Breaths /min

questions.text: Which of these is true regarding Pediatric ACLS guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In Infants after Intubation Respiratory Rate should be 20-30 Breaths /min

 

Option D: Correct. After intubation in infants, the recommended Respiratory Rate to maintain Adequate Ventilation without over-ventilation is 20-30 Breaths per minute.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Incorrect. Current Pediatric Advanced Life Support (PALS) guidelines indicate the use of cuffed endotracheal tubes can be beneficial in pediatrics to ensure adequate ventilation and prevent aspiration, with proper sizing and cuff pressure monitoring to minimize the risk of tracheal injury.

 

Option B: Incorrect. The depth of chest compressions in pediatric patients should be at least one third the anteroposterior (A-P) diameter of the chest, not equal to it.

 

Option C: Incorrect. In pediatric advanced life support, the initial dose for defibrillation is 2 J/kg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Pediatric Advanced Life Support, it is recommended to use cuffed endotracheal tubes with careful monitoring, provide chest compressions at a depth of at least one third the A-P diameter of the chest, deliver the first defibrillation shock at 2-4 J/kg, and maintain a respiratory rate of 20-30 breaths per minute for infants post-intubation.

 

Ref: American Heart Association Basic Cardiovascular Life Support Provider Manual -2020 guidelines

questions.text: Which of these is not an indication for Cardioversion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ventricular Tachycardia without Pulse

 

Option B. In the case of ventricular tachycardia without a pulse, immediate defibrillation, not cardioversion, is the treatment of choice according to Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) guidelines. This is because it is considered a life-threatening arrhythmia that requires immediate action.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Paroxysmal Supra-Ventricular Tachycardia (PSVT): Cardioversion can be used when vagal maneuvers and medications are not effective, particularly if the patient is hemodynamically unstable.

 

Option C: Atrial Fibrillation: Cardioversion can be indicated for atrial fibrillation to restore normal rhythm, especially if the patient is symptomatic or at risk for complications. It can be performed either electrically or pharmacologically.

 

Option D:  Atrial Flutter: Similar to atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter can also be treated with cardioversion to convert the rhythm back to normal sinus rhythm if the patient is symptomatic or at risk for complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardioversion is indicated for certain types of supraventricular tachycardias and atrial fibrillation or flutter to restore normal sinus rhythm. However, for ventricular tachycardia without a pulse, defibrillation is the immediate treatment required.

 

Indications for Cardioversion:

 

  1. Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia
  2. Ventricular tachycardia with pulse
  3. Atrial fibrillation
  4. Atrial flutter

 

Indications for Defibrillation:

 

  1. Cardiac arrest
  2. Pulseless ventricular tachycardia
  3. Ventricular fibrillation

 

Ref: American Heart Association Basic Cardiovascular Life Support Provider Manual -2020 guidelines

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is being induced for exploratory laparotomy for hemoperitoneum. Suddenly after giving Ketamine the anesthetist notices ventricular fibrillation on the ECG. The anesthesia consultant and resident immediately start CPR. What should be the ratio of chest compressions to ventilation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 15:2

 

Explanation:

 

In pediatric cardiac arrest with two rescuers, the correct ratio of chest compressions to ventilations is indeed 15:2. This is because in children, the cause of cardiac arrest is often respiratory in nature, thus the importance of ventilations is emphasized. When there is only one rescuer, the ratio changes to 30:2, which is similar to the ratio recommended for adults, to maximize the number of compressions delivered while still providing adequate ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a pediatric patient in cardiac arrest with two rescuers, the correct ratio of chest compressions to ventilations is 15:2 to ensure adequate ventilation alongside effective circulation.

 

Ref: American Heart Association Basic Cardiovascular Life Support Provider Manual -2020 guidelines

choices.text: Depth of Compression should be at least 5 cm
Complete Chest Recoil is allowed in between Compressions
If PETCO2 < 20 mm Hg, Improve the Quality of CPR
Chest Compression: Ventilation Ratio should be 30:2

questions.text: All are true regarding the quality of CPR except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) If PETCO2 < 20 mm Hg, improve the quality of CPR

 

Explanation:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

During CPR, if the end-tidal CO2 (PETCO2) is less than 10 mm Hg, it is an indicator that the quality of CPR may need to be improved, not the previously mentioned 20 mm

 

Ref: American Heart Association Basic Cardiovascular Life Support Provider Manual -2020 guidelines

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps to be performed in correct sequence for OHCA (out-of-hospital cardiac arrest) chain of survival guidelines?

 

  1. Advanced Life Support
  2. Early CPR
  3. Activation of Emergency Response System
  4. Rapid Defibrillation
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C, B, D, A

 

Explanation:

 

Chain of survival:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 6 links in the adult out-of-hospital Chain of Survival are:

 

  • Recognition of cardiac arrest and activation of the emergency response system
  • Early cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) with an emphasis on chest compressions
  • Rapid defibrillation
  • Basic and advanced emergency medical services
  • Advanced life support and post-cardiac arrest care
  • Emotional Recovery

 

A strong Chain of Survival can improve chances of survival and recovery for victims of cardiac arrest.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.text:
Assertion: General Anaesthesia is the preferred technique of anaesthesia in emergency obstetric surgeries. 

 

Reason: General anesthesia is more comfortable for parturients who have fear of needles or surgery.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion

 

Explanation:

 

General anaesthesia is the preferred technique of anaesthesia in emergency obstetric surgeries because it has a rapid and reliable onset and provides good control over the airway and ventilation. There are also less chances of hypotension as compared to neuraxial blockade.

 

Disadvantages of general anaesthesia in obstetrics:

 

  • Use of multiple drugs that cross uteroplacental barrier
  • Difficult airway in obstetrics
  • Risk of aspiration is increased in parturient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

General anesthesia is often the choice for emergency obstetric surgeries due to its rapid onset and control of airway and ventilation, not primarily because of patient comfort concerns regarding needle phobia or fear of surgery.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology 5th Edition Pg 855

choices.text: Tongue to mouth ratio is larger in adults than in pediatrics
Epiglottis is floppy in children
Epiglottis is at a higher level in children than adults
Larynx is funnel shaped in children

questions.text: Which of these is not true regarding difference between adult and pediatric airway?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tongue to mouth ratio is larger in adults than in pediatrics

 

Option A: This statement is incorrect. In pediatric patients, the tongue takes up relatively more space in the mouth compared to adults, which can complicate airway management, such as intubation or the use of airway adjuncts.

 

The anatomical differences between adult and pediatric airways are significant for clinical practice, especially concerning airway management during anesthesia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: This statement is correct. The pediatric epiglottis is more flexible or "floppy" and omega-shaped, which can make direct laryngoscopy and intubation more challenging compared to the stiffer adult epiglottis.

 

Option C: This statement is also correct. In children, the epiglottis sits higher in the neck (at C3-C4), which affects the angle of view during laryngoscopy and the approach for intubation.

 

Option D: True, the pediatric larynx is funnel-shaped, with the cricoid cartilage being the narrowest point, whereas the adult larynx is more cylindrical with the vocal cords typically being the narrowest part.

 

Educational objective:

 

Differences between Pediatric and Adult Airway:

 

 

Ref: Miller's Anesthesia 8th Edition • Page no: 2424

questions.text: A child with upper respiratory tract infection needs to be taken for emergency foreign body removal from esophagus. What would be the inhalational agent of choice in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sevoflurane

 

Option C: Sevoflurane is preferred in pediatric anesthesia due to its non-irritating properties, which make it less likely to cause breath-holding, cough, or laryngospasm. It also allows for rapid adjustment of anesthetic depth and quick emergence, which are particularly useful in emergency situations.

 

Sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice for induction in children, especially in the context of upper respiratory tract infection and the need for emergency foreign body removal from the esophagus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: While Desflurane has a rapid onset and emergence, it can be irritating to the airway, making it less ideal for patients with respiratory tract infections.

 

Option B: Isoflurane is known for its stability and control during anesthesia but can be pungent and irritating to the airway, leading to potential complications in patients with respiratory infections.

 

Option D: Halothane is less commonly used due to concerns about its side effects, including the potential for hepatotoxicity and cardiac sensitization to catecholamines. It also can cause airway irritation though to a lesser extent compared to other agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sevoflurane is chosen for pediatric anesthesia in the context of an upper respiratory tract infection because of its minimal airway irritation, rapid onset, fast emergence from anesthesia, and reduced likelihood of causing respiratory complications during induction.

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology 7th Edition Pg 1685

choices.text: Venous Air Embolism

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with controlled thyrotoxicosis and Carcinoma rectum was undergoing laparoscopic abdominoperineal resection. Intra-operatively there was a sudden fall in blood pressure and heart rate. On examination, a mill-wheel murmur was heard. The end tidal CO2 was observed to reduce from 40 to 10. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Venous Air Embolism (VAE)

 

Option A: Venous Air Embolism (VAE) is a known complication during laparoscopic surgeries where the operative site is at a higher level than the heart. The classic signs of a sudden decrease in end-tidal CO2, hypotension, and the presence of a mill-wheel murmur (a splashing auscultatory sound heard over the heart due to the presence of gas in the cardiac chambers) support this diagnosis. The drop in end-tidal CO2 is due to a block in pulmonary blood flow by air, preventing CO2 exchange.

 

A patient undergoing laparoscopic/thoracoscopy or procedure (e.g., craniotomy) in sitting, head up, park-bench, knee-chest positions that place the operative site above the right atrium carry an increased risk of VAE. Sudden decrease in end-tidal CO2 concentration (ETCO2) sudden hypotension/circulatory arrest and Mill wheel murmur indicate the diagnosis.

 

Most sensitive monitor to detect VAE: - TEE (Trans-Esophageal Echocardiography).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Let's evaluate all the options for the scenario of a sudden fall in blood pressure and heart rate with a mill-wheel murmur and a significant drop in end-tidal CO2 during laparoscopic abdominoperineal resection:

 

Option B. A thyroid storm is a sudden exacerbation of thyrotoxicosis symptoms, which include tachycardia, hypertension, and hyperthermia, not typically a sudden fall in blood pressure and heart rate. There are no findings here that specifically suggest a thyroid storm.

 

Option C. Significant blood loss would lead to hypotension, but it would not explain the sudden decrease in end-tidal CO2 or the mill-wheel murmur, which are more indicative of air entering the venous system.

 

Option D. Acute hypoxia would likely cause an increase in heart rate as a compensatory mechanism and would not explain the mill-wheel murmur or the sudden drop in end-tidal CO2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely diagnosis in a patient experiencing sudden hypotension, bradycardia, a mill-wheel murmur, and a significant drop in end-tidal CO2 during a laparoscopic surgery in a position that places the operative site above the right atrium is venous air embolism (VAE).

 

Ref: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anesthesiology 5th Edition Pg 599, 600.

choices.text: Central line insertion
Arterial line insertion

questions.text: The given set of instruments are used in? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Airway management

 

Explanation:

 

The instruments shown in the image are part of an airway cart. The equipment typically found in an airway cart is designed for managing the airway during anesthesia or in emergency situations. The contents of the airway cart usually include:

 

  • Laryngoscope: A device used to obtain a view of the vocal folds and the glottis, which is essential for endotracheal intubation.
  • Tracheal tubes of various sizes: These tubes are used to secure the airway by passing through the trachea.
  • Masks: Various types of masks to deliver oxygen or anesthetic gases.
  • Laryngeal mask airways (LMA): A device placed over the laryngeal inlet to provide ventilation.
  • Flexible fiberoptic intubation equipment: Used for intubation in difficult airway situations.
  • Retrograde intubation equipment: Tools used for intubation when conventional methods fail.
  • Front of neck access equipment: Devices for surgical airway access.
  • Equipment required for emergency invasive airway access: Tools needed for emergency tracheostomy or cricothyrotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central line insertion: This procedure requires different instruments such as central venous catheters, guidewires, dilators, and sterile drapes.

 

Option B. Arterial line insertion: This involves the use of arterial catheters, guidewires, and transducers, not typically found in an airway cart.

 

Option D. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR): CPR primarily requires defibrillators, chest compression devices, and basic airway management tools like bag-valve masks (BVM), but not the comprehensive set shown for airway management.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The instruments in an airway cart are specifically designed for various procedures involved in airway management, including intubation and emergency airway access.
